documents.title: that 's all from chimamanda
text: thanks so much to chimamanda for such erudite and illuminating answers .
if you want more discussion , she appears in an event looking back at half of a yellow sun ten years on , at royal festival hall , sunday 7 august , as part of southbank centre 's festival of love .
bobinchiclana asks : i love your writing but most of your protagonists are fairly middle-class or privileged .
have you thought of writing about people who are more in the margins of society in the case of nigeria in poorer rural communities .
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 3:06pm i am fairly middle-class and privileged .
perhaps not surprising that i mostly write what i know .
( however , ugwu , who is the soul of half of a yellow sun , is not . )
flungoutofspace asks : i 'm udoka , and i wanted to ask if you think of the effects of the interaction between traditional nigerian ( esp .
igbo ) values and christianity in modern nigeria , and what are the implications for fiction that attempts to address that combination ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 3:05pm i think it is catastrophic that we , in the name of christianity , are destroying our pre-christian heritage .
an ancient tree burned down during a vigil .
artifacts destroyed in the name of 'progress . '
we need to tell those stories .
if you are thinking of 'addressing that combination , ' please do .
you have a reader here .
charispd asks : how much of ifemelu 's repatriation to nigeria is based on your own experience ?
like her , do you feel at all in crisis because of how much time you spend in america away from your home country ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 3:04pm no .
i have two homes and feel very fortunate and grateful about that .
my best shoes are in my home in lagos , so perhaps that is a reason to feel some crisis .
must love black film and unicorns asks : as a writer i struggle knowing whether i am putting too much of myself into my characters .
how do you which parts of yourself to share and which to keep ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 3:01pm i wish i could really help .
i would say : trust yourself .
trust your writing .
trust your storytelling .
if you put in too much of yourself , and it feels emotionally true , then let it be ( and really , who is to say which is you and which is n't ?
kwa194 asks : ama ata aidoo has spoken glowingly about you .
how do you think the relationship between your and previous generations of african writers can help improve the literary scene across africa ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 3:00pm i adore ama ata aidoo .
her work has been very important to me , our sister killjoy is sublime , and the space she occupies in the world - as a feminist , thoughtful , brilliant , wise woman - has also strengthened me .
my generation owes a lot to hers .
we are able to write because they first did .
animaux asks : the advice given to the white male writer who wants to write about a bengali girl is very short-sighted , in my opinion .
it will only ensure that we have more books about middle aged white men and no books about disadvantaged bengali girls .
is that what we want ?

guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:38pm it 's unfortunate that you seem to assume that if a white middle aged man does n't write about a bengali girl , then the story of bengali girls will not be written .
there are in fact many bengalis who can write about bengali girls - and it probably does n't feel 'insurmountable ' to them .
and 'disadvantaged bengali girl ' is a very troubling way of framing an idea of a story .
it already suggests that this character will be seen through the lenses of her 'disadvantage ' alone .
people are people .
'disadvantaged ' people also have agency , and dream , and think , and desire .
sometimes how one frames a story determines whether or not we will see the fullness of a character .
sarah hannan asks : what excites you the most about being a new mom ?
what terrifies you the most about being a mom ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:32pm most exciting a new and unique kind of love has come into my life , glorious and joyful and encompassing and full of discovery .
most terrifying the anxiety-filled desire to protect her from everything and the terror-filled sense that i can not .
copacabana asks : black hair features prominently in americanah , as a burning aesthetic and political question .
even though it 's really no one 's business but hers do you still wish michelle obama had left her hair natural , if only to inspire little girls ?

guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:28pm no , i actually do not wish michelle obama had natural hair because then barack obama would not have won the elections and what a loss that would have been to the world .
when her daughters were younger , they were viciously attacked because their hair was twisted .
there is a very ugly side to american populism .
michelle and barack obama .
balce ceneta/ap

oyelola asks : in your novel half of a yellow sun which i read about my country 's history , i realised you did n't mention the two women who were murdered during nigeria 's first military coup january 15 1966 , latifat ademulegun and ahmadu bello 's first wife , why ?
also , during the first coup , civilians were shot in lagos and none of this was talked about in the novel .
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:26pm many things were not talked about in the novel .
i told the story i wanted to tell .
there are still many stories untold ( although there is mention of the attacks in lagos ) .
and thank you for mentioning the women who were murdered .

documents.title: 'sometimes while immersed in the multitude voices of others , you just might find your own '
text: koochacoo asks : what advice would you give to somebody who would like to write creativity , but has no idea where to start in terms of plotting a story , creating realistic characters and so on ?
how much planning goes into your own work ?
second question what are your thoughts on creative writing courses ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:20pm they can be helpful if you are clear about why you want to go and if you manage your expectations .
where to start ?
write .
just write .
start .
and read as much as you can .
read widely and read different things , and sometimes while immersed in the multitude voices of others , you just might find your own .

documents.title: 'to be human is to be flawed '
text: sarah madooh asks : in americanah , ifemelu is a strong woman who moved to a foreign country and moved back to nigeria on her own .
at the end of the novel , she invites obinze into her apartment .
ifemelu and obinze have had a somewhat tumultuous relationship throughout the novel .
even though they deeply loved and cared for each other , i ca n't help but feel disappointed by both ifemelu and obinze .
ifemelu follows her heart and goes back to her high school ex boyfriend who has since then become and adulterer .
obinze ignores his moral compass and cheats on his wife .
your book is wonderfully crafted and i have enjoyed reading it very much .
however , do you think that we should hold fictional characters to the same moral high ground as people in real life ?
or is that taking literature a bit too seriously ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:17pm i think you should read fiction however you want to .
we bring our own stories to the stories we read , and i respect that .
i sadly am not able to inhabit this moral high ground . '
too high for me .
i think that to be human is to be flawed .
and honest stories about human beings involves failures of different kinds .
darell philip asks : the late great chinua achebe is the past while you are the present and future great author to have emerged from nigeria .
how does it feel to be compared to a great as achebe , to as it were take the baton from him and run on and which of his novels is your favourite and why ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:14pm i think arrow of god is a classic .
one of the best novels ever written .
it is a paean to a changing world , and so beautiful and complex , and also so simple which is truly difficult to do .
qu1xot3 asks : having achieved renown outside of fiction ( for the ted talks etc ) , do you ever feel as though that celebrity makes it harder to write fiction ?
do you feel as though it creates a ( perhaps limiting ) set of audience expectations ?
or affects your own expectations ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:04pm no .
i feel as if i use two different parts of myself .
my writing matters more , gives me more joy .
but speaking about issues i care about has become extremely important to me , and something i feel passionate about .
sarah hannan asks : do you think you are more like olanna or more like kainene and why ?
do you think kainene is the stronger sister ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 2:02pm a friend said i divided myself in two and created each of the characters .
i 'm still thinking about it .
i certainly admire kainene more .
david philip inwald asks : how would you suggest one should write of a culture which is alien without cliche or stereotype ?
i am male , 50 and white and would like to write about a young bengali girl .
the responsibility feels huge ; do you think the task is insurmountable ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:59pm i think the first question is : why do you want to write about a young bengali girl ?
there are still wonderful stories to be told about 50-year-old white men .
if it is feeling unsurmountable , perhaps that 's a sign .

documents.title: 'complacency is cancerous for creativity '
text: montagandmildred asks : would you say you 're a confident person ?
do you write with the idea that people will want to read what you have to say in your mind or do you write purely for yourself ?
i tend to be my own worst enemy and believe that no one will enjoy what i have written .
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:57pm self doubt is part of the creative process .
i hate to have it but i also realise it is part of the process .
otherwise you become complacent , which is cancerous for creativity .
i generally write the kind of books that i like to read .
joyce hamya asks : what 's the best book you 've read so far this year ?

guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:54pm a book of poems by reginald dwayne betts called bastards of the reagan era which is magnificent , and i have just been reading every book by tessa hadley after reading her novel the past .
she has such great psychological insights into human beings , which is rare .
she is one of the best fiction writers writing today .
tessa hadley , one of the best fiction writers writing today ' according to adichie .
mccabe for the guardian
franzo asks : chimamanda , your book americanah was astounding and one of my favourite reads of all time .
i cried and laughed in recognition so many times .
i found the love story between ifemelu and obinze so believable , relatable and natural .
a lot of people shun romantic books as chick lit ' but i have often found very profound stories contain threads of romance within them , as well as their other themes .
what would be your advice to someone who wants to write about the authentic experience of love/relationships without succumbing to a cliche ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:51pm please write .
write .
write .
anna karenina is romance .
so is pride and prejudice .
so are so many great books .
just do it well .
good luck and best wishes as you write .
miren sanov asks : what is your view on christian missions in africa ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:48pm i have mixed feelings .
some have done humane and necessary work .
the irish priests in biafra were selfless and exemplary .
and others have encouraged , or been silent about , inhumane ideas in the name of christianity , such as the continuing oppression of gay and lesbian africans .

documents.title: on starting out : 'i wrote a large and terrible novel that was rejected multiple times '
text: whispering wind asks : would you be able to share how you were able to get your first break as a writer ?
did you have contacts or did you first publish short stories ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:45pm nope .
no contacts .
i was completely unknown .
i wrote short stories , got many rejections and then finally got an acceptance .
i wrote a large and terrible novel that i sent out and that was rejected multiple times .
and then i wrote purple hibiscus and a nice agent said she would 'take a chance on me . '
cranburyjo asks : half of a yellow sun follows the horrors of a conflict caused by ethnicity-based nationalism .
do you feel that is ever morally justified ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:44pm do i think horrors are justifiable ?
of course not .
do i think ethnicity-based nationalism is ever morally justified ?
of course .
oppression of an ethnic group usually leads to nationalist sentiments .
mwinji siame asks : if you could be any one of your characters for a day which one would you choose and why ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:41pm kainene .
i admire her very much .
joyce hamya asks : you 've made a prominent contribution to the gender equality discussion .

there 's been a lot of criticism lately of the un he for she ' movement : primarily that it tackles a kind of gender inequality that borders on hysteria in comparison to the inequality experienced by women in countries like syria .
having seen and experienced aspects of gender inequality in both nigeria and the states , do you think feminist movements in the western world overstate the problems we have to tackle ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:39pm i deeply dislike the word 'hysteria ' when it 's used in gender discourse .
it has been used for centuries to silence women 's legitimate concerns .
i do not at all believe that somehow the west does n't have 'real ' gender problems .
it does .
and it 's also too easy to simplify and flatten the experiences of women in places like syria .
i think we should accept that gender is a problem everywhere in the world and that it manifests itself in different ways and that all are valid problems .

documents.title: 'i so long for a world in which women everywhere are no longer taught to link shame and sexuality '
text: mariannemandu asks : one of my favourite things about your books is the way your female characters own themselves and their sexuality in such a natural and unselfconscious way .
how much feminist theory informed creating the characters , and what was it , if any ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:36pm have n't read much feminist theory and generally try to keep 'theory ' away from my creative space , if that makes sense .
i learned much about feminism from watching women in the world .
i so long for a world in which women everywhere are no longer taught to link shame and sexuality .
readsandreadsagain asks : i wonder if you could speak to how you feel about writer ' as a title or occupation .
the more i read the more i feel that writers are just wonderfully thinkers and feelers with a keyboard at hand .
do you feel like a writer , or do you see your project as something else ?
and do you feel that your writing ( the activity or the product ) affects the way you live your life ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:34pm quite happy with 'writer . '
i am still in awe , wondrous grateful awe , that i can do what i love and earn a living doing it .
i am at my happiest when my writing is going well .
and i am always watching and listening and 'collecting material . '
chiwetel ejiofor and thandie newton in the film adaptation of half of a yellow sun .
/british film/yellow sun bacon78 asks : hello chimamanda , i thought half of a yellow sun was fantastic .
i felt complete desperation at not knowing how it goes for kainene ; ever thought of writing a sequel ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:30pm thank you .
i felt the same way , not knowing what happened to her .
i was haunted by all the real families for whom this was their story .

documents.title: cultural labels give 'a lovely sense of being part of something larger '
text: tarastubbs asks : i recently finished americanah and thought it was wonderful .
it 's quite preoccupied with national and cultural labels ( nigerian , american , etc .
) , and their assumed associations .
to what extent do you find such labels enabling or limiting , both in your life and in your work ?

guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:28pm they are enabling a lovely sense of being part of something larger - and can be limiting , if you allow somebody else define the boundaries of the labels for you .
i do n't .
paballo makhubela asks : what do you think is the most important question a woman should answer about herself before she turns 30 ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:25pm i love this question and i wish i had the answer .

documents.title: 'people are different more than men and woman are different '
text: ekarithewriter asks : hi , shout out from malawi !
what tips do you have for writing female characters ?
i tend to write male protagonists as default .
when i examined the reasons why , i found that actually being a woman is more straight forward than writing a pov female character , just because of the majority of books i read growing up .
how do i write a character who is more than just a stand-in for the default male protagonist , and truly embodies the experience of moving through the world as a woman ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:23pm love to you my sister from malawi !
my main suggestion would be do n't think of the character as female ' because you might find yourself being limited by what a female ' should and should not be .
watch real people .
people are different more than men and woman are different .
id5236619 asks : how is it possible to deal with small town/provincial jealousy when you have chosen to make art ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:20pm jealousy of any sort is human .
art comes from a human place .
ara deji asks : what is the secret behind the unique way you name your characters and the philosophy behind it ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:18pm i love unusual names .
at my book-signing events , when i come across a beautiful name from any part of the world i write it down and plan to use it in my fiction .

i am igbo so obviously unusual igbo names mean even more to me.i think igbo names are so beautiful and so full of poetry and many of them are not often used because the same few post-christian names are now in circulation .
i love the idea of names as history .
walter shakespearean ude asks : i am male and i identify as a feminist .
someone told me she 'd rather identify as a proponent for gender equality than as a feminist .
that the feminist movement is too tainted , its image to an average nigerian too obstructive to effect a proper conversation .
this got me thinking about the two movements .
gender equality .
feminism .
is there any actual difference between the two ?
if there is , what is it ?
are their interests varied ?
if they are n't , how come some people fighting for the equality of the sexes feel less comfortable being seen as feminists than as proponents of gender equality ?

guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:14pm tell that someone to look up feminist ' in the dictionary.if you are a doctor who treats the heart and someone says oh , so you 're a cardiologist , you do n't say : no , i prefer to be known as a doctor who treats the heart.and thank you - we need more men to speak up .

documents.title: 'it is the absolute specificity of our stories that make them universal '
text: hammonann asks : i have not been able to finish half of a yellow sun .
i was growing up in liberia during the biafran war , and then liberia suffered through their wars , and the book felt so personal .
i 'm a white american , but my heart stays in liberia .
will you write a more over-arching book about west africa , and the shared struggles ?
i have enjoyed your other works .
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:10pm no , i will not be writing an over-arching book ' about the west african struggles . '
i am just reading a lovely book called in our strange gardens , about the nazi occupation of france .
it is painful and beautiful .
it would never occur to me to want the writer to write a more over-arching book about the struggles in western europe . '
it is the absolute specificity of our stories that make them universal .
ikpohenry asks : do you think it is possible for me to write from a gender-neutral point of view ?
if yes , is it advisable ?
i ask this because i write , by default , through a female eye only for some readers to go but why would you write like that ?
i bu nwanyi , are you not a male ?

now , i honestly can not write from a male point of view mainly because males do n't know how to express things they feel unlike females , an example being my mother who 'd throw herself on the ground and beat her chest when told that a relative had just died whilst my father would remain mute .
i can write through the eyes of a female being because i have witnessed , first hand , how most of them express themselves .
but i 'm not sure i should keep writing that way because of some foul comments that are inboxed to me .
should i keep on writing how i know best or should i write neutrally ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:06pm i do n't know what writing neutrally means .
i think people are different , more than men and women are different .
so you may think men are not expressive but there are some men who are .
just as there are women who are not expressive .
so your male character can in fact be expressive .
i generally think people should write what they think they do best and biko rapukene comments na inbox .
if you choose to write , you have to accept that there are people who will not like what you write , and that is perfectly okay .
you do n't have to please everyone .
fashionlimbo asks : how do you come up with your rich characters ?
ifemelu and obinze are so full of life , so real , but so different from one another .
as an aspiring writer i struggle with creating believable , real , almost tangible , characters .
how do you manage this ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:03pm my suggestion would be to watch real people .
watch and notice things about them , and then invent their inner lives based on what you 've noticed .

documents.title: chimamanda is with us now
text: melania trump , a foil of sorts for ivanka ' in adichie 's recent short story .
betancur/afp/getty images chimamanda has started answering your questions , beginning with this from clareyesno : i thought your melania trump story was scarily plausible !
what made you want to write about her ?
and what are your thoughts more generally on trump can he win , why is he appealing to so many americans , and how can anyone combat his lies and aggression ?
guardian contributor chimamandaadichie 03 august 2016 1:01pm it was ivanka trump and not melania who interested me .

it 's impossible to truly know people from their public appearances , of course , but i thought she seemed too intelligent and reasonable to truly believe her father would be a good choice for the united states .

and so i imagined her as a character who loves her father and , knowing him to be pathologically needy , makes a show of supporting him while secretly supporting the candidate she truly believes is the better candidate .
so i thought of using melania as a foil of sorts for ivanka .
i also just wanted to write a story in which it 's the women in his life who have agency and are full of their own personal motivations .
oh , and i had a few delicious chuckles while writing .

documents.title: post your questions for chimamanda ngozi adichie
text: chimamanda ngozi adichie is one of nigeria 's greatest writers , able to articulate both intimate personal relationships and the great sweep of history .

her novels purple hibiscus ( 2003 ) , half of a yellow sun ( 2006 ) and americanah ( 2013 ) focus on social upheavals , from the biafran war to transatlantic racial politics , all told through affecting , utterly true-to-life characters .

most recently she has written a short story about donald trump 's wife melania , imagining her as an ignored and sexually frustrated figure ; her tedx treatise we should all be feminists has become a huge success , with beyonce quoting it on her song flawless , and the swedish government decreeing that every child should receive a copy .
ahead of a southbank centre event where she discusses half of a yellow sun ten years on , chimamanda is joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat .
post them in the comments below , and follow the chat from 1pm bst on wednesday 3 august .
